data.title: How to hit debug break point for AspNet C# console app.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Create aspnet C# console project using yeoman. 
2. Open project folder in VSCode.
3. Set proper .net environment and configuration for debugging.
4. Update launch.json with properties:
              "stopAtEntry": true.
               "program": "${workspaceRoot}/bin/Debug/dnx451/win7-x64/TestCSharpWithVSCode.exe",
5. Set "debugType": "portable" in project.json.
6. Build project and set the brake point at entry point under program.cs (main function).
7. Now start debugging and verify app behavior.

Actual:
1. Debug break point is not hitting.
2. Should stop at entry point as stopAtEntry set to true.

Question: Am I missing something here? What are the settings I need to add to hit debug break point? 
I am following instructions from https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/blob/master/debugger.md

data.title: Keep history independent of splits
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.0.0 (1.0.0) fa6d0f03813dfb9df4589c30121e9fcffa8a8ec8
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.4

If I split my editor and then navigate through history, navigation will linearize my history such that I cannot step back in history in my in-focus editor split without inadvertently affecting my out-of-focus editor.

For example, if I have editor splits 1 and 2 and my navigation history looks like this (with time moving from left to right):

```
Split 1: File A              --> File B
Split 2: File X  --> File Y            --> File Z
```

If my in-focus editor is split 2 and I want to navigate back in history to File X, I cannot do so without also causing Split 1 revert back to File A, which is very undesirable.

data.title: When minimizing vertically using Win+Left, the cursor is lost
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the editor with a random text file and maximize it.
2. Place the cursor somewhere and see it blink.
3. Press Windows + Left so that VS Code occupies half the screen.
4. See that the cursor is lost and that if you type you cannot see it. If you maximize it again you can see what you typed.

This issue is not 100% repeatable.

data.title: Word wrap broken in debug repl

data.title: Column selection should either not include ALT or it should be configurable

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: 10.0.10586.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Type in multi-line text in VS Code
2. Hit the key combination for column selection (`SHIFT + ALT`)
3. Notice that if you key-up `ALT` before you keyup `SHIFT`, the hidden menu bar will show (normal `ALT` keyup behavior)
### Desired behavior

For us users that keep the menu bar hidden, it is not a great experience to see the menu bar appear from hitting `ALT`.  It would be helpful if the keybindings for column selection were configurable (I couldn't find a way to configure this in keybindings json config), or if it by default didn't include `ALT`.

data.title: Hover popups while debugging don't work when using Unity3D.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.3
- Unity 5.3.4f1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Configure Visual Studio Code with Unity as described at: https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/runtimes/unity
2. Start debugger and set breakpoint

See screenshot: Hovering on the method parameter works and I can see its values.
Hovering over the private object variables (see _startPiece, _id, etc.. in the screenshot) does **not** work. No hover popup is displayed.

data.title: Joh/zonedebt
nls: wrong translation of 'DEBUG CONSOLE'
data.body:
- VSCode Version: alpha

The german translation of 'DEBUG CONSOLE' has become 'KONSOLE DEBUGGEN' which means 'to debug the console'. The correct translation (used elsewhere) is 'DEBUGKONSOLE'.

This indicates that 'debug' in 'DEBUG CONSOLE' is translated as a verb and not as a noun.

Please add a translation comment to make it clear that 'debug' is a noun.

data.title: Can't navigate to "find" field of replace widget with shift-tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.6
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Press `Ctrl-H` to open replace widget
2. Realise you want to edit the "find" field
3. Press `Shift-Tab` repeatedly
4. Focus just cycles between the close and replace buttons

Interestingly, cycling using `Tab` goes around more of the buttons, but then tabs out of the widget and starts inserting tabs in the document (see end of screencast)

![replace_blackbird](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1737376/14952766/3d1803f4-105b-11e6-8a7d-a4eb0a47736c.gif)

In conjunction with #4566, makes for a very frustrating experience :) I don't mind the "replace" field being focused by default, as long as I can `Shift-Tab` to the "find" field if what I want isn't in there.

data.title: Add a menu for extension commands
May fixes and debt

data.body:
Introduce `LinkedMap` and `LRUCache` as replacement for our caches that do the `Map` and counting themselves without recency condition.

For https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/5621

data.title: Scrolling issues windows 10 switching desktop

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VS Code Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home Build 10586.218

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open two desktops.
2.  Open VS Code in one of the desktops with scroll-able content. Scrolling works fine now.
3. Switch to the other desktop and back to VS Code. Now scroll the same content using touch-pad. It does not scroll, looses focus.

data.title: debug doesn't work on node v6
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. install node v6
2. generate express application
3. open the app folder with vscode
4. open console and run `node --debug bin\www`
5. attache to node process with vscode
6. set break point to `users.js:line:6`
7. and navigate in the web browser to '/users'

it works with node v5.10

data.title: VSCode eats memory and slows down my Macbook Pro
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.0.0
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
One plausable reason:
1. Install "npm commands"-extension and run your project from VSCode
2. After a while the computer acts like an Windows Vista install on an old computer (imagine that!)

However:
Even though I did stop the npm stuff (didn't uninstall it though) it still drains my computer of all its powers.
So I'm not 100% sure it relates to the extension.

I'm sorry if this bug report is hard to understand. I'm writing this out of memory. I can try and reproduce it and update it if you haven't heard anything about this before.

data.title: Frequent svn command attempts on file save

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.0.0 - OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Save any file. (Seems to often pop up while editing unsaved settings.json, too.) Note that this is on a fresh install of VSCode 1.0.0 on a new Mac without Xcode or developer tools installed. Not sure why changing settings.json would repeatedly try to initiate svn, though.
